column4: i'm looking to find a way to remotely (ssh) unlock the encrypted filesystems on a server after a reboot... has anyone done this?
automatically throw commands on remote machines? that's definitely doable. try searching for ssh key authentication :)
is openssh-server running when it hasn't unlocked anything but the boot partition?
when the system boots, it has a BIOS password which is bypassed because of WOL boot; it loads the boot partition; then has to decrypt the other partitions before it can boot
as this is a server, I cannot have it automatically unlock the encrypted contents
I need to enter the key to unlock the encrypted filesystems manually
what is encrypted? the whole filesystem or just the data?
then you're screwed, you need a keyboard
that's what I was afraid of. I think I need a hardware console server to enter it via console
or you might choose to reinstall the thing "clear text" and only encrypt the sensitive data
another option could be to use an usb dongle with the key on it, but it's not so intuitive
that adds physical security to the list of protections ;) right now someone could literally steal the server and get nothing.
if you only encrypted the data, one could literally steal the server and get a linux installation. whoo, exciting.
full encryption plus an offsite encrypted tunneled rsync means 100% safe
and they would see what type of encryption scheme and start working away on  it
and then get a cluster of space ships from star wars to crack aes512 and get the results in a few thousand years, sure
and anyway, anybody capable of cracking that kind of encryption (read: aliens) can surely tell whether a filesystem is or isn't encrypted.
